content.body:
Text within a
must also be wrapped in a

?
Steve^, nop. but it might be handy to have some extra hook for styling purposes
Aha, Text is flow content
Just making sure I can reproduce your answer from the docs :)
well, it's just like a div... just with some meaning tacked on :>
True, though I wasn't sure in that content either
context
"when in doubt, validate" ;)
makes everything easier
For example on this section:   http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#e-mail-state   it does not appear to list the actual value for the email state, "email"
It is listed in the table above, but it'd be nice to not have to cross-reference
"actual value"?
The value to go into the type attribute
Hixie: in what ways is the websocket protocol spec moving forward from the (what seemed like) a break down in communication between WHATWG and IETF
micheil, it's a tad more complicated than that
okay, explain then
heh, could have expected that
because I'm totally lost at the moment as to what's going on.
we're still communicating
okay, it sounded like there was a break down of communication.
I'm not quite sure where it is heading though, but everyone is still there and nobody has been ousted
okay
it's mostly that people have somewhat varied views on how extensibility is to be addressed
well, are we still going ahead with the draft76 style packet format, or moving towards the VI one?
erm, Framing Take IV
ranging from WG in control to wide-open (and also way more complicated)
hmm..
Hixie changed the framing
well, from an implementors perspective, using the Framing Take IV is a hell of a lot simpler.
did he?
it now uses 64-bit
okay, you've lost me there; let me read up on the spec.
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete/network.html#protocol-overview
frames are now
frame-type frame-length data
one moment, safari's busy crashing trying to load the compelte one :P
with frame-length being a length encoded as 8 octets
(the above is multipage)
okay, cool
so what, is it still using \x00 and \xFF as the start/end delimeters?
or are we using just a message is frame-length long
a message with a type that is frame-length long
okay, example?
they're in the spec?
one octet for type (only text and closing supported currently); eight octets for lengths as unsigned 64-bit int; data blob
so, example packet may be: <0xFF><11><hello world>
<11> being a big endian  64 bit int
<hello world> being UTF8 encoded binary data?
yes
okay
and, if the content was say, binary, it might be something like <0xFE><11><binary data>
where <binary data> would be 11 bytes of binary data
(if binary data were to be supported)
would it make more sense to have one frame-type reserved for metadata, where an example might be:
<0xF0><13><Encoding=UTF8>
which would tell the server that the client expects data to be encoded with UTF8 encoding
that requires API changes
on top of which we do not want to support more than one encoding for text
(this would be sent onconnect by the client, but could also be sent by calling ws.setEncoding(enc) )
where enc maybe a DOMString of either: "binary" or "utf8"
seems simpler to just have a different frame type
okay
that sounds fair enough then
but then, how do I change between binary and utf8 data?
(without requiring massive changes)
I'm thinking that when the server receives that Encoding=UTF8, it will then encode all out-going messages as UTF8 data
if it receives Encoding=Binary, it will then encode all out-going messages as raw binary data
because otherwise the server cannot send binary data
unless you make everything always binary data, and only have the clients decode to utf8 or something
but that's not a good direction to go
once binary support is there the server can do whatever it wants
and the javascript library will just handle binary and strings
and in the transition period you can tell the server with a simple text message that your client supports binary
yeah, but if the data coming in on the "message" DOMEvent is UTF8 encoded, then you'd have to do odd stuff
from the application layer
a different frame type would be exposed differently in the API
(maybe not for all future frame types; but binary and strings get their own primitive; but since JS doesn't have one for binary; we're waiting)
okay, I think it'd make sense to emit just one event "message"
and then to change the encoding of those message events, you call a client side API of setEncoding("...")
no
okay
just like with XMLHttpRequest send() will just be overloaded
and the data attribute of the message event will be a ByteArray (or whatever it ends up being) rather than a DOMString
(it's of type any after all)
okay, so inside ws.send's function, it'd be something like: if(typeof data === "string") { send as string } else if(typeof data === "bytearray") { encode to binary }
would that also mean that the onmessage api would need to do that same, or would it get given the content type?
eg, server sends a binary message, then a utf8 message, then another binary message
would the events still be: message, message, message, message
and would you still get (data) as the arguments to the function call?
it would be just message
or would you get: (data, binary)
but data would be of varied type
okay
so I'd need to manually check for typeof data
you'll always need to do some kind of check; but yes
okay
and there's no more usage of that end delimiter format, right?
having said all this, nobody has patched their browser implementation just yet
there's just one packet format, no high or low byte messages or what ever they were?
micheil, right (that's not coming back)
(I'm just wanting to get up to speed)
I kinda got lost wading through the 200 odd emails in 1 or so days last week
well, the binary/text stuff has remained the same; it's just the packaging that's different now
from an API point of view nothing really changed
yeah, it's kind of crazy
yeah
as long as both text and binary share the same actually packaging around them when sent on the wire, I'm cool with that.
Wikipedia is distracting.
and writing a complete test suite is hard
even "just" for XMLHttpRequest
discovers apt-get install pastebinit
discovers he is incapable of writing for any period of time now
gsnedders: I'd blame Twitter
(Also, IRC)
the main part is getting into the right mental frame to be able to write.
micheil: A length delimited or sential delimited frame?
preferably a length delimited frame
I would prefer sentinel delimited, with the sentinel being "I have nothing more that needs writing"
would be nice if dev.w3.org had a favicon
Workshiva: hmm, that could work
encounters a page for which html5 parser is more useful than chromium's \o/ ( http://www.ishmael.org/Education/Writings/ )
"Note: There will be at least one such element, by definition." — I don't get how there will be.
There will be at least one such element, by definition.
Ah
tries to work out why
Oh, the "corresponding name property", I think…
Philip`: You had a bug on SpiderMonkey about Math.sin varying between x86 and x86-64, no?
gsnedders: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=531915 ?
Philip`: Yeah, thanks
Philip`: Also, if you want more things to test in your canvas test suite, you could take a look at http://codingforums.com/showthread.php?t=198624
No one much seems to have commented on the srcdoc issue.
http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issue-100-objection-poll/
has his doubts about whether srcdoc is actually very useful, to be honest
seriously tempted to ask if i can use http://alexkessinger.net/story/html5-brief-one-paragraph as the abstract for the spec

I notice that the intention is for the UA to replace the content of <time> with a locale-specific form. I think it'd be helpful to have a set format describing how the UA would do this, or else it is difficult to use the value in the right context

For example it may be important to the content to stress that a date was on a saturday. So I could do  Saturday <time datetime="2010-08-07">8th August</time>.   But for all I know the UA could convert this to   Saturday Sat 8th Aug 2010
is a little skeptical of the idea of locale-specific rendering here.
Steve^: Where does it say that?
Hmm, it seems not to?  Good.
Sounds like a bad idea.
In the time element text

Here is another way that could be marked up. In this example, legacy user agents would say "today", while newer user agents would render the time in a locale-specific manner based on the value of the attribute.
Oh, wait.
^ quote
That's non-normative.
What it actually says in normative text is "If the datetime attribute is present, the user agent should convey the attribute's value to the user when rendering the element."
is unsure whether that's useful.
What does non-normative mean?
Means "not really part of the standard, just meant to help you understand the actual requirements, ignore it if it contradicts normative text".
Oh
The text I refer to isn't even inside the non-normative "box"
But there seems to be something in the bindings section
It's in <div class="example">, thus non-normative.

When the time binding applies to a time element, the element is expected to render as if it contained text conveying the date (if known), time (if known), and time-zone offset (if known) represented by the element, in the fashion most convenient for the user.
I didn't read the code...
I'm a little confused now to your opinion on the matter
Is the spec right or wrong?
Steve^: It looks like you're right
I'm right that it's silly?
Maybe
As an aside, this non-normative stuff sounds misleading and shouldn't be in the spec if it's not valid
Well, "a locale-specific way" gives the UA a license to do pretty much anything it wants
which is impossible for content authors to predict
File a bug.
I think it's one of those problems that won't actually occur
Why not?
It seems that there are two seperate use cases here: One for text that should be easily cross-referenced to a calendar and the second for showing dates in a locale-specific manner
That UAs will magically all decide on formats that don't include the day of week
Sure
But why do we actually want it to be locale-specific?
That would just be weird.
Like a Chinese person seeing dates in Chinese on an otherwise English page?
I think these two use cases conflict... with the former I probably want the value of "today" or "Saturday" to persist, with the true date hidden until asked for
AryehGregor: More like "Let the user configure the browser to show a sensible date format instead of that American rubbish"
AryehGregor, 10/02/2010 vs 02/10/2010  for 10th Feb

And if you're trying to guess whether 6/7/2010 refers to June 7 or July 6, you now have to not only take into account whether the site you're on is mainly American or British, but also try to guess whether it used <time>, and if so, what your browser thinks the right order is for you?
Seems like a recipe for confusion.
In the markup, but it could still be ambiguous in the display.
If the user wants it to be
hmm
I think the likely case is that the display will always be informal
But I somewhat agree
The first use case is the important one
Which?
Calendar integration
Yes.
Also <time pubdate> is nice for search engines.
yes
I don't think <time> should be displaying stuff differently from what its contents indicate.
Authors can script that if they like, it doesn't need to be on the browser level.
Alternatively, users could configure their browser to do it via an extension or something.
It shouldn't be mandated by the spec.
It would result as <time pubdate datetime="2010-05-25" />  25th May
Seperate, to avoid the browser messing with your styles
Thus, you can dynamically show "Today", "Yesterday", "25th May"
The browser can't decide that for you, but twitter styles feeds would insist on it
AryehGregor, I should file a bug in bugzilla?
Yes, you can use the form at the bottom of the WHATWG version of the spec.
Post the URL of the bug so I can voice support.
If you want to track the bug, it's better to file manually
That way you get properly registered as reporter
What is the different between the two versions?
The spec form is anonymous
Ok, http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/enter_bug.cgi ?
(Is that the right one for the right spec?)
Yeah.
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10318
hola boyz
